channel.title: May 16 client traps

item.title: May 16 client traps
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Teh Freak:

As for injecting, im sure if it werent in a general area, they might be a little suspicious (sp?), and also, thanks for not being an ass, and sharing a little, i expanded on my test app for the error stuff and noticed about the trace, something stupid i had came out "test:28 test:23 test:18 test:13 | java.lang.Exception | de.D(50)" but yea, thanks for sharing that, but i still fail to see how it would matter if we renamed methods and fields, from what i can tell, its just looking at class names, but if im wrong, oh well, but yea, thanks for not being an ass about it.

EDIT: i looked a little more at the report method and saw that the "string_20" stored the method names
[code]java.lang.Exception
at test.method3(test.java:28)
at test.method2(test.java:23)
at test.method1(test.java:18)
at test.main(test.java:13)[/code]
but it does nothing with them

Interesting, I sort of abandoned looking at the method after I realized it was being passed a complete Throwable. Should go look more carefully.

Read full topic

item.title: May 16 client traps
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

moparisthebest:

[quote author=Teh Freak link=topic=3430.msg34829#msg34829 date=1148167971]
also if you inject code, you're fucked, it reads the line # which the error was on, aka the exception, but whatever, still nice finds, hope to progress

that I believe is easy enough to get around, we will just have to stop making the injected code pretty, and inject it all on one line so its not noticed, messy but it works[/quote]

No, even decompiling and recompiling it fucks up the LineNumberTable attribute (as does BCEL instrumentation, unless done carefully).

Teh Freak:

As for renaming, the only part that is risky, is renaming Classes. Renaming fields and methods wont do anything, because it automatically puts the method name in the error report, but the class name isnt like that. For example, i just copied/pasted the error methods, made my own little error, and this was the output
"test:11 | java.lang.Exception | de.D(50)", test = the class name, thats the ONLY feature that it reads, so as long as you rename the class names back, i fail to see no trouble in it, and also if you inject code, you're fucked, it reads the line # which the error was on, aka the exception, but whatever, still nice finds, hope to progress

You're discounting the information stored in the rest of the RuntimeException object
Take a look at java.lang.StackTraceElement, which you can retrieve by calling Throwable.getStackTrace() (java.lang.Throwable is the superclass of all Error and Exception objects).

Read full topic

item.description:
@philodespotos wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

Too bad you're too stupid to look.

You begin with an insult. You must know something about proper social interaction that I missed out on somewhere. He's obviously making an effort; he's not just some dipshit posting nonsense. And yet, that was the contentless crap you decided to respond with.

pplsuqbawlz:

Yeah I do mind, it's just the same as me doing the work for you now isn't it.

Or, were you not inclined to act like an egotistical 8 year old, it could be helping another person along. You don't even provide clues, just unfounded assertion. There's this strange idea out there in the world that "helping people" is a good thing. It's not doing someone's work for them, but rather encouraging them to continue their work by providing what you might happen to know. "Collaboration." Try lookin it up.

This will indubitably receive the "but I don't need help, I'm oh-so-far-advanced that I just laugh from my mighty perch, and you may rest assured that this perch is deserved without any justfications" answer which is your accustomed style, but, for God's sake, you could at the very least make an effort at not being an outright prick to people who are trying to do something productive.

While I assume that most of us have come to accept the fact that, for whatever reason, your ego fragilely rests upon your professed abilities at cheating in a game for 12 year olds, that doesn't mean you are required to adopt the behaviour of their target audience.

Grow up, learn to show respect to others like a fucking rational human being.

item.title: May 16 client traps
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ok, here is my zkm log parser, it outputs it to an xml file which is easy as hell to open and get values from, the only thing that needs working on is storing/renaming the overridden methods (as it is now, if there are 5 methods named "a" in the class it will only store one of the new names) im welcoming suggestions on that, otherwise here it is(attached to post as well):

import java.io.*;
import java.util.Properties;
/**
 * Author: moparisthebest
 * <p/>
 * Converts zkm ChangeLog.txt into easy to use
 * xml format. Overridden methods still not
 * successfully handled.
 */
public class changeLogParser {
    public static int[] renamedAsKey = {1, 0};  //switch the zero and the one to switch key/content(duh?)
public Properties xmlDoc;
public int classes, fields, methods;


public static void main(String[] args) {
    new changeLogParser(args);
}

public changeLogParser(String[] args) {
    xmlDoc = new Properties();
    try {
        File file = new File("ChangeLog.txt");
        FileInputStream fistream = new FileInputStream(file);

        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(fistream));
        String line = "";
        String[] classNames = new String[2];
        while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
            if (!line.contains("NameNotChanged"))
                if (line.contains("Class:")) {
                    classNames = getNames(line);
                    xmlDoc.setProperty(classNames[0], classNames[1]);
                    classes++;
                } else if ((!line.contains("(")) && (line.contains("=>"))) {
                    String [] fieldNames = getNames(line);
                    xmlDoc.setProperty(classNames[0] + "." + fieldNames[0], classNames[1] + "." + fieldNames[1]);
                    fields++;
                } else if ((line.contains("(")) && (line.contains("=>"))) {
                    String [] methodNames = getMethodNames(line);
                    xmlDoc.setProperty(classNames[0] + "." + methodNames[0], classNames[1] + "." + methodNames[1]);
                    methods++;
                }
        }

    } catch (Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    if (writeToXML(xmlDoc, "ZKMchangeLog.xml", "zkm changeLog in xml format"))
        System.out.println("Successfully made ZKMchangeLog.xml\nZKM Renamed:\n" + classes + " Classes\n" + fields + " Fields\n" + methods + " Methods\n");
    else
        System.out.println("Error outputing ZKMchangeLog.xml");
}

public String[] getMethodNames(String line) {
    String[] tokens = line.split("\\s");
    String[] results = new String[2];
    for (String token : tokens)
        if (token.contains("("))
            results[renamedAsKey[0]] = token.substring(0, token.indexOf("("));
    results[renamedAsKey[1]] = tokens[tokens.length - 1];
    return results;
}

public String[] getNames(String line) {

    String[] tokens = line.split("\\s");
    String[] results = new String[2];
    results[renamedAsKey[0]] = tokens[tokens.length - 3];
    results[renamedAsKey[1]] = tokens[tokens.length - 1];
    return results;
}

public boolean writeToXML(Properties xmlDoc, String fileName, String comment) {
    try {
        File file = new File(fileName);
        FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(file);
        xmlDoc.storeToXML(fos, comment);
        return true;
    } catch (Exception e) {
        return false;
    }
}
}

edit: this is a better way: http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,3539.msg34752.html#new

Read full topic

item.title: May 16 client traps
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Actually they could, it's there game.
And it doesn't matter, if your internet cuts out, they've worked a way around it.
They use what I call, and thought they should have used from the start: Fingerprinting.

You should listen to Krichevskoy, though he's behind me as far as this stuff goes, he's lightyears ahead of everyone else.
And I'm not just being cocky. AS far as parsing ZKM? That's easy as PIE to do. But the thing is, you don't need to. A well written deobber works despite having naming conflicts.

There's an age old error in saevions deobfuscator. It has to do with its field identification routines.
Fields are not identified by just name type and class, but access and heap-size too.

Hope I cleared up some misunderstandings <3.[br][size=1]Posted at: May 19, 2006, 08:02:01 pm[/size][hr]Wow, I take that back, krichevskoy isn't just a little bit behind me... There's another reason why you can't use a renamed client. He didn't mention it, but mopar, when he does, you'll look like a complete fool. There's a LOT more reason than just what he said as far as renaming goes.

Reading the zkm log.... You know, I'll actually help with that :-p. Krich is on the right track, using hte zkm log == good.

Read full topic

item.title: May 16 client traps
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Krichevskoy:

[quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=3430.msg34023#msg34023 date=1148061502]
[quote author=Nerice link=topic=3430.msg33964#msg33964 date=1148055184]
Why not update the bot to the client, instead of using wrappers?

thats how richyt's updater used to work, pretty messy though

why cant we just comment this out?

// throw Class27_Sub11_Sub3_Sub6.getRuntimeExceptionWrapper(runtimeexception, "me.getAppletContext(" + ')');
[/quote]

Presumably there are conditions under which they expect to receive an error, such as when there actually is one. If the rest of your client is screaming "ERROR!" and disconnects but the device specifically included to transmit extra information about that error is silent, then that's a bit of a tip isn't it? I don't know if they would actually check that (at least right now), but it's a potential.

About sending the original title...do you know what Class42 was called originally? How about that method356 was actually the seventh a(BII)V method? It's possible and a good solution, but we would need
1) an automated tool to compile a list of oldname->newname (I know zelix dumps one)
2) an intercept in the error method to edit the RuntimeException's source characteristics (plus a good way of querying the list in 1)[/quote]

they couldnt ban people for the client disconnecting but not sending information about it, because that could happen if the internet connection cut out, however they could do crappy things like intentionally causing an error just to check if its renamed (I somehow doubt they would be smart/desperate enough to do this, but who knows? the potential is always there)

zelix dumps a changelog of what it renames (which would be the original, expected names) it wouldnt be too hard to write a program to parse the zelix changelog and convert it to a better format, perhaps xml? then while renaming to what we want just change the value in the xml sheet to the new value, all this would be done while updating

the bot would only need a new class which we would write that we could send in a runtimeexception, and it would return a new, renamed runtimeexception, this I believe would be the correct way to handle it, and although it would be annoying to write it wouldnt be too hard, if anyone else thinks this would be the proper way to go about this just say and Ill write up the whole thing ;D

Read full topic

// throw Class27_Sub11_Sub3_Sub6.getRuntimeExceptionWrapper(runtimeexception, "me.getAppletContext(" + ')');[/quote]

Presumably there are conditions under which they expect to receive an error, such as when there actually is one. If the rest of your client is screaming "ERROR!" and disconnects but the device specifically included to transmit extra information about that error is silent, then that's a bit of a tip isn't it? I don't know if they would actually check that (at least right now), but it's a potential.

About sending the original title...do you know what Class42 was called originally? How about that method356 was actually the seventh a(BII)V method? It's possible and a good solution, but we would need
1) an automated tool to compile a list of oldname->newname (I know zelix dumps one)
2) an intercept in the error method to edit the RuntimeException's source characteristics (plus a good way of querying the list in 1)
